children.name: overestimate
children.definition: to guesswrongly, by thinking that theamount,level, orcostof something is bigger, more expensive etc than it really is:
examples: People overestimated the risk of catching the disease.
overestimate how much/how long etc
We overestimated how long the journey would take, and arrived far too early.
overestimate[S]
We thought the job would cost $5000, but this was an overestimate.

children.name: underestimate
children.definition: to guess wrongly, by thinking that theamount,level, orcostof something is smaller, less expensive etc than it really is: đánh giá quá thấp
examples: ▪ They underestimated the amount of time it would take to finish the work.
underestimate how much/ how long etc
▪ You must never underestimate how much I love you.
how difficult/ how important etc
▪ Don’t underestimate how good the other team is, or how hard they’re going to play.
badly/greatly underestimate
▪ They had badly underestimated how many lifeboats would be needed.
underestimate[S] sự đánh giá thấp
▪ There could be 50 people at the wedding, but this is probably an underestimate.

children.name: guess wrong
children.definition: to guess incorrectly: đoán sai
examples: I guessed she was over sixteen, but I guessed wrong.

children.name: be wide of the mark
children.definition: to guess incorrectly - use this when sb is not at all close to being correct: quá sai
examples: The movie was expected to gross millions, but that forecast was wide of the mark.
be seriously/hopelessly wide of the mark
All the opinion polls turned out to be hopelessly wide of the mark.

children.name: have a guess
children.definition: British /take a guessespecially American /ˌhæv ə ˈges, ˌteɪk ə ˈges/  to guess an answer, amount, or number - use this especially when you aretellingsomeone to do this: dự đoán
examples: ▪ ‘How much rent do you pay for your apartment?’ ‘Take a guess.’
have a guess at dự đoán về
▪ Have a guess at the answer, then check it with your calculator.

children.name: guess
children.definition: to try to answer a question or form an opinion when you are not sure whether you will be correct :
examples: I’d say he’s around 50, but I’m only guessing.
guess right/correctly/wrong
If you guess correctly, you have another turn.
guess what/who/how etc
You can guess what happened next.
guess at
We can only guess at the cause of the crash.
What star sign are you? No,letmeguess.
difficult/hard/easy etc to guess
It’s hard to guess his age because he dyes his hair.

children.name: estimate
children.definition: /ˈestɪmeɪt, ˈestəmeɪt/  to say how muchsomething will cost,how manyof something there are etc, partly by calculating and partly by guessing:
examples: ước tính ước đoán ( bao nhiêu )
estimate (that) ước đoán về
▪ Police estimate that over 10,000 people took part in the demonstration.
estimate something at $350/£400 etc ước đoán cái gì có giá 350 đô, 400 bảng
▪ His personal fortune is estimated at £150 million.
▪ The mechanic estimated the cost of repairs at $350.
estimate how much/how many etc ước tính bao nhiêu
▪ Can you estimate how much fabric you will need for the curtains?
estimated[adjective] được đoán
▪ More classrooms are urgently needed, at an estimated cost of $300,000.

children.name: make a guess
children.definition: /ˌmeɪk ə ˈges/  to guess something, especially when you are trying to answer a question or explain how something might have happened:
examples: dự doán, ước đoán
▪ I’ve no idea where I lost the keys. I couldn’t even make a guess.
make a guess at/about/as to ước đoán về
▪ It’s possible to make a guess at who the woman in the story might be.

children.name: put sth at
children.definition: put something at/ˈpʊt something æt/  put the cost/the value/somebody’s age etc at something to guess that the cost, value etc is a particular amount without trying to be very exact: án chừng, đoán chừng
examples: ▪ I’d put her age at around 35.
▪ The cost of the war was put at more than $10 billion.

children.name: speculate
children.definition: /ˈspekjɑleɪt/  to think about or discuss something in order to guess what its causes or results might be: suy đoán
examples: ▪ We don’t know why the prehistoric stone circles were built. We can only speculate.
speculate about/on/as to suy đoán về
▪ Edward began to speculate on what life would be like if he were single again.
▪ People have been speculating about interstellar flight for years.
speculateverb[ I ]GUESSsuy đoán
to guess possible answers to a question when you do not have enough information to be certain
_I don't know why she did it - I'm just speculating.
_A spokesperson declined to speculateonthe cause of the train crash.
_Journalists are speculatingaboutwhether interest rates will be cut.
_[ + that ]The newspapers have speculatedthatthey will get married next year.

children.name: speculation
children.definition: when you guess about the possible causes or effects of sth without knowing all the facts, or the guesses that you make, especially about something that is happening in politics or public life - used especially innewsreports:suy đoán
examples: speculation that
There is speculation that the president is ill.
speculation about/on
speculation about the future
pure/mere speculation(= not based on any knowledge )A government official yesterday dismissed the reports as ‘pure speculation’.
wild/idle speculation(= unlikely to be true )Such fears are wild speculation.
amid speculationShare prices increased amid speculation that the Bank of England would cut interest rates.
intense speculationThe reason for his resignation was the subject of intense speculation.
widespread speculationThere was widespread speculation about his political plans.
renewed speculationThe move has prompted renewed speculation that an election will be held in April.
press/media speculationShe appealed for an end to press speculation about her marriage.
lead to/prompt/give rise to speculation(= result in it )This development led to speculation that she was about to resign.
fuel speculation(= make it increase )The announcement has fueled speculation that the company will be the target of a takeover bid.
dismiss speculation(= say that it is not true )He dismissed speculation that he might run for president.
end speculationSmith has ended speculation about his future by signing a new contract.
be a matter for speculation(= be unknown )The precise nature of the deal is a matter for speculation.
be the subject of speculation(= be thought and guessed about )His role in the affair has been the subject of speculation in the press.
speculative[adj] an opinion, explanation etc that is speculative is based on guessing and not on facts: suy đoán, mang tính suy đoán
Theories of the origin of life are partly speculative.highly speculative based almost completely on guessing and probably not correct
Until further research has been done, any figures that I can give you are highly speculative.entirely/purely speculative based completely on guessing
The papers were full of talk of Lucan’s whereabouts, all of it entirely speculative.

children.name: guess
children.definition: an attempt to answer a question or make a judgement when you are not sure whether you will be correct :
examples: I’d say she’s about 35, but that’s only a guess.
make a guessI didn't know the answer to question 7, so I just had to make a guess.
have a guessBritish English,take a guessAmE: Go on, have a guess at how much it cost.|Take a guess. How many people do you think showed up?
hazard a guess(= guess something, when you feel very uncertain )No one at this stage is prepared to hazard a guess about the outcome of the elections.
a rough guess(= one that is not exact )This is just a rough guess, but I think it would cost about $50.
a wild guess(= one made without much thought or information )I made a wild guess and I got the answer right first time.
a lucky guess‘How did you know?’ ‘It was just a lucky guess.’
a good guess(= one that is likely to be right )I'm not sure how old she is, but I can make a good guess!
sb’s best guess(= one that you think is most likely to be right )My best guess is that it will take around six months.
an educated/informed guess(= a guess based on things that you know are correct )Stockbrokers try to make educated guesses as to which stocks will do well.
an intelligent guessAnalysis of the archaeological site will help us make an intelligent guess as to what it was used for.
an inspired guess(= a very good guess that you make suddenly )It’s hard to believe he got that right with just an inspired guess.
my guess is (that)My guess is there won’t be many people there.
at a guessBritish English(= used when saying that you are making a guess )I'd say it was built around the turn of the century, at a guess.
I’ll give you two/three guesses(= used to tell someone that it should be easy for them to guess the answer to their question )‘Where is he?’ ‘I’ll give you three guesses.’
‘Who’s her new boyfriend then?’ ‘I’ll give you three guesses!’

children.name: guesswork
children.definition: when you try to understand sth or find the answer to sth by guessing, because you do not have all the information you need: sự phỏng đoán
examples: It’s important to find out what consumers want to buy, rather than relying on guesswork.
At the beginning, the police investigation was largely based on guesswork.
it was pure/sheer guessworkspoken use this to say that you found out something by guessing : chỉ là phỏng đoán thôi
‘How did you know where she’d gone?’ ‘It was pure guesswork.’

children.name: conjecture
children.definition: formal guesses that are based on information that is not complete: phỏng đoán, ước chừng
examples: a matter for/of conjecturesomething that people can try to guess but cannot know họ chỉ có thể phỏng đoán thôi
It’s a matter for conjecture who wrote the original text in the fifteenth century.
pure conjecturebased only on guessing, and not on facts chỉ là phỏng đoán
The judge dismissed the evidence as pure conjecture.

children.name: estimate
children.definition: 1a calculation of the value, size, amount etc of sth made using the information that you have, which may not be complete :
examples: We just need an estimate of the number of people who will come.
at/as a rough estimatemaking a rough estimate
At a rough estimate, staff are recycling less than a quarter of the paper we buy.
2a statement of how much it will probably cost to build or repair sth
estimate for
The garage said they’d send me an estimate for the work.
make an estimateInsurers have to make an estimate of the risk involved.
give an estimateThe builder gave me an estimate of £10,000.
provide (somebody with) an estimateCould you ask him if he can provide us with an estimate?
put an estimate on something(= say the amount that you think something is )It is impossible to put an estimate on the value of the manuscript.
an estimate puts something at somethingIndependent estimates put the number of refugees at 50,000.
base an estimate on something(= use something as information to give an estimate )The government based its estimate on data from the 2008 census.
a rough/approximate estimate(= not exact )Can you give me a rough estimate of how much the repairs will cost?
an accurate/reliable estimate(= fairly exact )It’s hard to put an accurate estimate on the number of people affected.
a conservative estimate(= deliberately low )By conservative estimates, 2.5 million people die each year from smoking cigarettes.
an official estimate(= accepted by people in authority )According to official army estimates, more than 500 rebels had been killed.
current/recent estimates(= ones that are accepted now )According to current estimates, the country can expect 200,000 visitors in the next three years.
the latest estimates(= the most recent ones )The latest estimates are that sea levels could rise by about 20 cm by 2050.
earlier/previous estimatesThese amounts are much higher than those given in previous estimates.
the original estimate(= the one given at the beginning of a process )The final cost was nearly three times the original estimate.
according to an estimateAccording to some estimates, an acre of forest is cleared every minute.
estimates range/vary from ... to ...Estimates of the number of homeless people in the city range from 6,000 to 10,000.

children.name: guess
children.definition: to guess correctly that something is true, or guess the right answer to sth:đoán ra, đoán được
examples: ‘Are you Dan’s brother?’ ‘Yes, how did you guess?’
Luckily, I guessed the right answer and won the prize!
guess what/who/where etc
Guy looked at her face, and guessed what she was thinking.
guess (that)
Sally guessed that he had been drinking for most of the afternoon.
Detectives guess the attacker must be aged from 25 - 30.
From their behaviour it was easy to guess that they were married.
guess the truth
They had already guessed the truth about their son’s disappearance.
guess right
Which hand have I got the chocolate in? If you guess right you can have it.

children.name: you’re getting warm
children.definition: spoken say this when sb’s guess about sth is nearly correct:bạn sắp đoán được rồi đấy, gần đúng rồi đấy
examples: ‘Where are you going? Egypt, Morocco?’ ‘You’re getting warm!’

children.name: my guess is
children.definition: spokensay this when you are telling sb what you think has probablyhappenedor will probably happen: tôi đoán là
examples: my guess is (that)
▪ My guess is that they’ve been delayed in a traffic jam.
▪ My guess is she’ll move back to the States after the divorce.

children.name: I bet
children.definition: spoken say this when you are fairly sure that sth is true or something is happening, although you cannot prove this: tôi cá
examples: He’ll be really pleased to see you, I bet!
I bet (that)
Come and sit down, I bet you’re exhausted.
I bet that the meeting will be cancelled again.

children.name: off the top of my head U
children.definition: off the top of my headspokensay this when you are guessing a number or amount and you have not checked it exactly: nói ngay không cần suy nghĩ
examples: Off the top of my head, I think that the figure is about 25%.
‘What’s the painting worth?’ ‘Three million or so,’ he said, off the top of his head.

children.name: a guess that is based on very little information
rough guess U
children.definition: rough guess the answer you give when you are trying to guess a number or amount but are not able to be exact:đoán mò, đoán đại
examples: I’d say Mrs Roberts was about 35, but that’s only a rough guess.
make/take/have a rough guess
It’s terribly difficult to calculate, but I could make a rough guess and say the cost will be abouthalf a million.
at a rough guess
‘How long will the journey take?’ ‘At a rough guess, about six hours.’

children.name: hunch
children.definition: a strange feeling that you know the answer to something, even though you have very little information to help you to guess:linh cảm
examples: It’s just a hunch, but it’s possible the murderer may have been a woman.
hunch about
‘How did you know the answer?’ ‘I just had a hunch about it.’
sb’s hunch
My hunch is that she’s his mother.
hunch that
My hunch that he was lying turned out to be correct.
have a hunch (that)
I had a hunch that something like this would happen.
I have a hunch that Jodie may be planning a surprise party.

children.name: wild guess
children.definition: a guess, especially an answer, that seems stupid or is very likely to be wrong: đoán già đoán non
examples: This is a wild guess, but is the answer Michael Jackson?

children.name: a shot in the dark
children.definition: a guess that you make when you have no information at all, so that it is almost certainly wrong: đoán mò
examples: Let’s see if she’s at Fiona’s house. It’s a shot in the dark, but we’ve got to start looking somewhere.
